overview: 1 Chronicles retells Israel's history from Adam through David's reign, emphasizing worship, the temple, and God's faithfulness. Written after the exile, it encourages the returned community about their spiritual heritage.

verses.text: Oh give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever!
Yours, O LORD, is the greatness and the power and the glory and the victory and the majesty, for all that is in the heavens and in the earth is yours.
And you, Solomon my son, know the God of your father and serve him with a whole heart and with a willing mind, for the LORD searches all hearts.

passages.title: David's Prayer of Thanksgiving
passages.summary: David's magnificent prayer acknowledging that everything belongs to God and comes from His hand, offered as the temple preparations are completed.

passages.title: The Ark Comes to Jerusalem
passages.summary: David brings the ark to Jerusalem with great celebration and establishes ongoing worship before it.

facts.text: The first nine chapters consist almost entirely of genealogies, tracing Israel's lineage from Adam to the post-exilic period.
Chronicles was likely written by Ezra the scribe after the Babylonian exile, to remind returned exiles of their identity and heritage.
Unlike Samuel and Kings, Chronicles focuses almost exclusively on Judah and the Davidic line, omitting most northern kingdom history.
The book emphasizes worship and the temple more than political history, showing what matters most to God's people.

figures.name: David
figures.description: Presented primarily as the worship leader and temple planner, this account emphasizes David's spiritual legacy over his failures.

figures.name: Solomon
figures.description: Receives David's charge to build the temple and serve God wholeheartedly, inheriting detailed plans and massive resources.

videos.title: 1 Chronicles Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores how Chronicles retells Israel's story with a focus on worship and hope.
